'Paying for rubbish bags: a good idea or not?
In many countries, people throw away a lot of rubbish. Some people think it's a good idea to make people pay for each bag of rubbish they throw away. This might seem like a good way to reduce the amount of rubbish we produce. But it's not that simple.
In some towns in the United States, people have been paying for rubbish bags. The idea is that if people have to pay for each bag, they will think twice before throwing things away and will try to recycle more. But it's not working as well as expected.
In one town, people were charged 80 cents for each rubbish bag. At first, people threw away fewer bags, but then they started putting more rubbish in each bag. This made it harder for the rubbish collectors to do their job. Some people even started dumping their rubbish illegally.
The only good thing that happened was that more people started recycling. But this might not have been because of the new system. Some people were already recycling before the new system was introduced.
The researchers who studied this found that making people pay for rubbish bags doesn't really make a big difference. It might reduce the amount of rubbish by a little bit, but not by much. This is because people don't really change their habits that much just because they have to pay a few cents for each bag.
Maybe we should think about other things that affect how much rubbish we produce, like how much money we have and how much time we have to recycle. Charging people for rubbish bags might not be the best way to solve the problem of rubbish.'

Work and life. Many people are not happy with their jobs. They feel unvalued and overworked. Even those who have achieved success often feel bitter behind their fame. Loving your job used to be enough, but now people want more. They want to know how their job affects them as a person, their mind, character, and relationships. 
We need to think about what makes work fulfilling. It's not just about creating wealth, but about having a good life, discovering new talents, and meeting new people. 
Many people are unhappy with their jobs. Doctors are stressed, accountants are worried about their profession's ethics, and architects are not using their imagination. Middle managers are losing their confidence. 
We need to rethink what work means. It's not just about being busy, but about being happy and fulfilled. We need to give people a chance to design their own jobs and work with people they like. We need to learn to communicate better, not just talk about our work, but have real conversations. 
For example, hotel workers are often underused. They are intelligent and lively, but they work long hours for low pay. Hotels could be more than just a place to sleep. They could be cultural centers where people from all over the world meet and learn from each other. 
Work is a relationship. It's not just about obeying rules, but about being independent and working with people you respect. We need to rethink what we mean by "work" and make it more meaningful.

'Broadcasting: How Technology Shapes Society'
The word "broadcasting" originally meant spreading seeds widely by hand. It's not just an agricultural metaphor, but also a symbol of modern optimism. It's about planned growth, spreading something to a wide audience. The metaphor assumes a central location with resources to spread and reproduce. The question is, why did a new technology that transmitted words and pictures electronically develop in a way that fit this metaphor?
Television, as a technology, is related to two-way communication like the telephone and telegraph. It's surprising that, from the start, it was designed as a centralised "mass" medium. This fits with the social and economic structures of modern societies. Attempts to organize it differently remained just that - attempts.
Two lesser-known alternatives are worth mentioning. In the 1930s, some people in Britain experimented with two-way television as an alternative to the phone. Radio amateurs built their own TV transmitters and receivers, and many people in the country tried it out. However, big businesses and the government stepped in and set standards, making it difficult for these grassroots efforts to continue.
Television was also seen as a potential competitor to the film industry in the US. In many countries, people mostly watched TV in public settings, not at home. In Britain, for example, most people saw TV in public places. This was even more true in Germany.
The idea of grassroots, two-way TV was unlikely to succeed. Instead, TV systems based on collective public reception were developed in several countries. Manufacturers wanted to sell TV sets to the public, and the idea of centralised broadcasting to a dispersed audience fit well with modern society.
As people's living standards improved and they entered the consumer society, they could afford to buy TVs and enjoy entertainment and cultural experiences at home. This is happening globally now. There is a connection between social modernization and the dominant structures of broadcasting.
Centralized broadcasting was a way for governments to reach citizens efficiently and produce a sense of national unity. The pervasiveness of these processes and interests made centralized broadcasting the natural choice for radio and TV.
What's missing from this story is the idea of broadcasting as a way to promote democracy and equal access to information. In the formation of broadcasting policies between the wars, the idea of broadcasting as a means of securing equal access to resources was important. TV is changing, and the term "broadcasting" might become outdated. In that case, this metaphor will be seen as a specific way of organizing audio-visual technology during a particular phase of social modernization.

'Music and Theatre
I used to think that opera is mainly theatre. But after working at an opera house, I learned that music comes first. That makes sense. However, I come from a world of theatre, where words are more important. In theatre, there is no one directing the action once the show starts, and the performer and audience speak the same language.
When attending a musical performance, some people may not understand music well, but they can still appreciate the skill of the performers. It's like watching an athletics match - we know athletes work hard, but we can't do what they do.
Theatre audiences have different expectations. They don't always understand the skill of acting and aren't impressed by something that seems easy to do. They ask actors how they memorize their lines.
In contrast, music audiences come with different expectations. They may not understand the music, but they can still appreciate the skill of the musicians. I think music can learn from theatre about how to connect with the audience.
Music performances can be theatrical, with passion, humor, and intimacy. But the way music is presented, with strict dress codes and a focus on the conductor, can make the audience feel like they are not part of the performance. Some people even applaud between movements, which can disrupt the music.
There are efforts to make music more accessible and break down barriers. I remember a remarkable opera that combined music and community. It was a powerful experience that brought people together.
I wish music could be more like theatre, taking risks and being more radical. Sometimes, this can happen when performances are held in unusual locations, which can be uncomfortable but exciting. I want music and theatre to thrive and for more people to enjoy them.'

Making Movies
When we turn a book into a movie, we have to make some changes. We need to cut out some parts and make it shorter. This can be frustrating, but it can also be interesting. I worked on a script and saw that I could take out a lot of dialogue and descriptions and still get the same message across. This doesn't mean the original dialogue and descriptions were unnecessary. It's just that the way we tell a story is different in a book and a movie.
Movies can be very engaging. We can get caught up in the story and feel like we're part of it. But when the movie ends, we go back to reality. We don't feel responsible for the time we spent watching the movie. Some people don't think movies are an art form. They just see them as entertainment.
The film studio where I worked was a confusing place. There were many small rooms with identical furniture, and it was hard to find your way around. The studio didn't encourage visitors, so most people who worked there knew where to go. But for those who didn't, it was very confusing.
Many people want to make a movie. There are many books and courses on how to do it. Some people even make movies on their own with a small camera. One director, Robert Rodriguez, made a movie called El Mariachi for just $7,000. He became famous and was able to make more movies.
In the past, movie directors took time to learn their craft. They started by working behind the scenes and then made their own movies. Today, with the rise of independent filmmaking, aspiring directors have to be more self-sufficient and take risks.

I grew up in a place called West Earlham, where the houses were close together and not very nice. There was a factory nearby that made chemicals, and sometimes the smell was bad. I don't remember much from my childhood, but I do remember looking out of my window and seeing the houses getting smaller and smaller. My mother was a strict person who always ironed and cleaned. She was also very particular about how people behaved. She didn't like it when I played in other people's gardens or when I didn't sit still for a long time. She had some friends, but they were not very friendly. They would talk about boring things like the weather and their aches and pains.
As a child, I went to school when I was five years old. My mother would take me to school on a bike with a special seat for children. Sometimes I would walk with other children in the street. I liked the summer holidays because I got to see the world outside of West Earlham. I would visit a man who lived next door and listen to his stories about the sea. I also went to a charity event once where I got lemonade and tried to learn about a charity for children.
My mother didn't like politicians and thought they were only interested in money. She didn't like the idea of charity and thought people were only doing it to get money. She took me to the museum on Sundays and we would walk around looking at paintings. She wasn't very interested in art, but she would make jokes sometimes. One time, she saw a painting of a Roman soldier and said, 'I wouldn't want to meet him on a dark night!'

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the odd-numbered side. It was getting dark and the air was humid and misty. I knew this street from when I was a child. There were many houses and shops, and I knew some of the people who lived there. As I walked, I noticed that the houses got smaller and the yards got smaller too. Over time, some of the houses had changed. The porches were no longer made of wood, but of metal. Some houses that used to be homes were now stores, and some stores were now homes.
I visited a friend who lived in a big, open space that used to be a warehouse. He wanted to make it feel more like a home, so he put up a wall made of plastic to divide the space. He also put in a kitchen and a living area. He wanted the kitchen to be a place where he could cook for friends or work with clients.
I also read about a famous writer named Bruce Chatwin. He loved to travel and write about his adventures. His first book was very successful and people loved it. However, he sometimes made up stories or changed the truth to make them more interesting.
I also thought about swimming. I like to swim in my pool and watch the rain fall on the water. One day, I had an idea to swim across Britain to reach the sea. I wanted to get away from the usual routine of swimming laps and explore new places.
Most of us live in a world where everything is labeled and explained. But sometimes, we need to get off the beaten path and explore to discover what's really out there. Swimming, walking, and cycling can be a way to do that.

'Charles Darwin thought that humans cry for no special reason. He was probably wrong. Later, scientists found that crying is important for people's relationships. A psychiatrist named John Bowlby showed that crying helps mothers and children bond. Some people think that children cry because they feel helpless. But why do adults still cry? It seems that the sound of crying is not as important as the way it looks. Crying might have helped early human groups feel safe and connected. We might cry to show sympathy for people who are suffering. We might also cry when we hear beautiful music or a moving speech. Sometimes we cry when we watch a sad movie, but this is more likely to happen when we're with others. It's clear that crying is important for people's social connections, but scientists are still studying this.'

'Global Warming: How Hot Will It Get?
We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get and how will it affect our lives? Most people have some idea of what global warming is, but nobody is sure about its consequences. A warmer climate will bring changes to the weather all over the world. This will have big effects on plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans have learned to use natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support our population. Any changes to these resources are important.
The problem is that we don't know exactly how the world will change or what is causing these changes. We do know that human actions have increased the amount of certain gases in the air, which are related to temperature. These gases are building up and are already affecting the climate. However, our understanding of the Earth's heat balance is limited, so we're not sure about the current or future situations.
Scientists think that the Earth has warmed by about 6C over the past century. They believe that this is not a natural process and is partly caused by human pollution. Researchers have been studying how the climate will change if the temperature rises. They use special computer programs to predict the effects of global warming. These programs are not perfect and are slow and expensive to use.
Most people agree that the rate of change will be faster than anything we have experienced before. The computer programs suggest that the average global temperature will rise by 1-3.5C by 2100. Sea levels will rise by 15-95 cm, and there will be changes in rainfall patterns. Extreme weather events, like heatwaves and floods, will become more common in some areas.
Climate change will affect the natural environment and humans. It could change the places where plants and animals live, the mix of species, and the benefits they provide to humans. This will affect our resources, including food, water, and settlements. Some areas will be affected badly, while others might benefit. For example, some scientists have found that warmer temperatures have helped increase wheat production in Australia.
However, many of the predicted effects of global warming will be negative. Small changes in climate can affect the availability of water, leading to droughts and water shortages. This will be a problem in arid and semi-arid regions, as well as areas with high demand or pollution. The Mediterranean Basin is an example of this, with decreasing rainfall and changes in seasonality.
Climate change will also affect glaciers, which will impact on vegetation, wildlife habitats, and human structures. The Arctic's ice cover might melt completely, making sea transport and oil and gas exploration easier, but also increasing the danger from icebergs. The most dramatic effect will be the rise in sea levels, caused by the expansion of the ocean and melting ice. This will lead to flooding and inundation, affecting many coastal cities, including London, New York, and Tokyo. Many people will lose their homes and livelihoods, and this could lead to millions of environmental refugees.'

'Art and its meaning can be difficult to understand because the things we consider works of art are often separate from our everyday experiences. We tend to think of art as something that exists independently, like a painting or a building. But art is actually about the way it affects us and the experiences it creates. When we separate art from our daily lives, it becomes hard to understand its true significance. This is because art is often associated with a special history and prestige, which can make it seem distant and unconnected to our everyday experiences.
To truly understand art, we need to connect it to the ordinary things that happen in our lives. We need to see how art is connected to the world around us, just like how geologists study the earth by looking at its different forms and conditions. We also need to forget about the art itself for a while and focus on the things that make it meaningful, like the way it makes us feel or the experiences it creates.
Many people enjoy things that are often not considered "art" in the classical sense, like movies, music, or comic strips. This is because they find enjoyment in the everyday experiences that art provides, rather than just admiring it as a separate entity. The key to understanding art is to connect it to our everyday lives and see how it affects us, rather than separating it from the world around us.'

'Music in the Future
Music is an important part of our lives. Technology has changed the way we listen to music and how we make music. In the past, we had more opportunities to listen to music through the radio, TV, records, and CDs. However, this has led to a decline in live music performances and fewer jobs for professional musicians.
In the future, we can expect to have even more ways to listen to music and make music. New types of music will emerge, combining different styles. Technology will also help people to create and perform music, making it easier for more people to be involved.
But what about the future of music education? We need to make sure that people can learn to play different instruments and continue to play them throughout their lives. This means changing the way we teach music and how we assess progress. Musicians will need to be able to teach people of all ages, work with large groups, and have good communication and management skills.
It's important to raise the profile of music and make people realize how important it is. Those involved in music education need to work together to show that music education is of high quality.
Overall, the future of music will be shaped by technology, new musical styles, and changes in the way we learn and teach music.'

Actors often get criticized for their work. Some people don't understand what actors do, and actors themselves can make it worse by talking about their craft too much. An actress named Pavlova once said, "If I could explain it, I wouldn't dance it." Actors should focus on their work rather than talking about it. 
A famous actor named Paul Scofield said, "An actor's work has life and interest only in its execution. It withers away in discussion." He means that an actor's work is most meaningful when they're performing, not when they're talking about it.
A review of a play called Hamlet says that the actor who played Hamlet, Adrian Lester, did a great job. He was able to switch between being a boy and a man, and his performance was simple and confident. He used his body and voice well to bring the character to life.
So, what is acting? Is it just imitating someone or is it something more? Who or what makes the actors' bodies come alive? This is the main question about the life of the theatre.
One director has a special way of rehearsing. He calls it "dropping in." The actors sit quietly while someone else is speaking, and then they think about what it means to them and wait for the impulse to speak. 
The perfect theatre should make you feel like your presence matters. The staff should feel like they're part of something special, too. The auditorium should be designed to make the audience feel close to the performers. It's important to have a sense of the past in the theatre, like old stone steps in a church. And, of course, you can't please everyone with every play. You have to take a risk and try something new.

As the cubs grew, we introduced them to different foods, like cereals and fruit. They started to go on walks at night, and we would join them. They would play and chase each other, and sometimes they would nip at us. We had to be careful not to get too close.
As the summer went on, the cubs grew bigger and stronger. They started to venture out of their enclosure and explore the surrounding area. We noticed that other badgers were visiting our field, so we built a special home for them, with tunnels and chambers. The cubs loved their new home and spent most of their time playing and exploring.
Now, the cubs are almost fully grown, and they don't need us as much. We still see them occasionally, and they come to say hello before they go off into the night. They have their own territory now, and we're proud of the home we built for them.

Charles Darwin thought that living creatures changed over time through a process called evolution. He believed that the creatures that were best suited to their environment were more likely to survive and have babies. But Darwin had trouble explaining why peacocks had such big tails. He thought that the females liked the males with the most beautiful tails, just for the sake of being beautiful. However, his friend Alfred Russel Wallace thought that the hens must be choosing the males with the best tails because they have some other quality that is not obvious to humans.
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still trying to figure out why peacocks have such big tails. They are studying the behavior of the peacocks at Whipsnade, where they live in a semi-wild environment. The researchers have found that the hens do prefer the males with the most beautiful tails. The males with the most eye-spots on their tails are the most attractive to the hens. However, it's not clear whether the males with the best tails are also healthier or more successful in other ways.
The researchers are trying to find out if the males with the best tails are also better in other ways. They are comparing the babies of the males that the hens find attractive with the babies of the males that the hens find unattractive. If the babies of the attractive males are healthier and grow faster, it would suggest that the hens are making a practical choice. There is also a theory that the males with the best tails are less likely to have parasites, and that this is what makes them more attractive to the hens. The researchers are still studying this to see if it's true.
Finally, there is a mathematical theory that suggests that the peacocks' tails evolved because of a feedback loop. If a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, their sons will inherit their father's tail and their daughters will inherit their mother's preference for long tails. Over time, this could lead to the evolution of the peacocks' tails. This theory would also support Darwin's idea that the females are choosing "beauty for beauty's sake".

**Natural Talents**
Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. In fact, we share almost 98% of the same genes. This means that the things that make us different from animals are recent developments. Our physical abilities, such as making art, must have come from a small number of genes. This is a big responsibility for a few genes.
Studies of animal behavior have shown that many things we thought were unique to humans are not. For example, chimpanzees use tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Even monkeys have a simple language.
The only things that really set us apart from animals are art and language. But if art is unique to humans, it's strange that our ancestors didn't create art for millions of years. The earliest known human art is from around 35,000 years ago, in the form of cave paintings and statues.
Some people think that human art is different because it's non-utilitarian, made for pleasure, and learned rather than instinctive. But these claims are not entirely true. While some animal behaviors are functional, human art is not. And while animals may not make art for pleasure, they may still enjoy it. For example, birds sing during the breeding season, which suggests they may enjoy their songs.
The fact that human art is learned, rather than instinctive, is also not unique. Some birds learn their songs from their parents, and humans learn their art from others. In fact, human art styles change quickly, whereas animal behaviors remain the same.
There is a famous example of chimpanzees creating art. Two chimpanzees, Congo and Betsy, were taught to paint and created many beautiful works of art. Some of these paintings were even sold at an art show in London. This shows that the distinction between human and animal art is not as clear-cut as we thought.

**Talking Shop**
Have you ever gone to a store and bought more things than you planned to? Shops use tricks to make you spend money. Here are some of their secrets:
**Fresh and Clean**
Supermarkets know that people like to buy fresh food. They put fresh fruit and vegetables near the entrance or display them with plants. They also make sure the bakery smells delicious to make you want to buy more. The colors they use, like green, make you feel like you're buying healthy food.
**Displaying Products**
The way products are placed in the store is important. Supermarkets use computers to see which products people buy most often. They put these products in easy-to-reach places. They also put special offers in places where people tend to look.
**Spreading Out**
Supermarkets put everyday items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. You have to walk past other products to get to them. This way, you see more things you might want to buy.
**Less is More**
Some stores make their products look special by putting them on fewer shelves. This makes you think the products are exclusive. The store's design is also important. It makes you want to buy more.
**The Total Bill**
Food shoppers care more about how much they spend overall than how much each item costs. Supermarkets put a mix of cheap and expensive products together to make you spend more.
**Pricing**
Chain stores put a lot of thought into pricing. They make sure the prices are just right to make you buy. They also use special prices to attract customers.
**Lighting**
Stores pay attention to lighting. Chain stores want it to be like natural light so you can see the colors of the clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make food look more appealing.
**Paths and Promotions**
Some stores divide their floors with different carpets. This makes you walk along a path and then into the sales area. Some stores use wood or marble for the paths to make you feel more welcome.
**In-Store Advertising**
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of food that looks delicious. Some stores even have special trolleys with screens that show you ads as you shop. This is designed to make you buy more things on impulse.

In the 13th century, many types of apples were grown in Britain. One popular variety was the Old English Pearmain, which was sweet and delicious. Another variety was the Costard, which was used for cooking. The name "costermonger" comes from the way it was sold in the streets.
In the 16th century, Henry VIII ordered a fruit expert to visit France and learn about growing apples. This expert brought back new varieties, including the famous Pippin, which was grown in an orchard in Kent.
When people sailed to new countries, they took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. In North America, a man named John Chapman, also known as Johnny Appleseed, planted apple seeds and grew new trees.
In the 19th century, a farmer in Iowa discovered a new apple variety that was delicious. It was named the Delicious apple and became very popular. Another famous apple variety was discovered by a woman named Maria Smith in Australia. She found a small tree growing in a pile of discarded fruit and transplanted it. The tree grew and produced green apples, which became famous all over the world.
Today, apples are grown all over the world, but many varieties have been lost. Some people are working to save the old varieties and promote diversity in apples. We need to value and protect natural diversity in food to benefit everyone.

Advertising is not working well. It's not just because of the economic crisis. Advertising has been declining since 1989, even before the crisis started. The problem is that advertisers are not adapting to the changing economy. They still think about big groups of people and big media, but nowadays, there are many smaller groups and more media options. This means that even big brands are not targeting the right people.
Think about your own shopping habits. You buy many things, but most of them are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands, but not many. Over a year, you probably buy less than 400 different brands. Compare this to the 32,500 brands that are advertised. It's clear that most advertising is wasted.
When you watch TV, you might see one or two commercials for brands you buy or might buy. But the rest are probably wasted. You might think you're special and not affected by advertising, but most people are not. In reality, nobody buys most of the advertised brands.
Advertising has to reach many people to find the right ones. But it's hard to know who will respond. Even direct mail shots don't always work. Media advertising is cheap, but it's not perfect. It's like trying to hit a target with a big net. You might catch some people, but many will slip through.
To make advertising more effective, it needs to be more targeted. The goal is to reach a small group of people who will respond. Any campaign that can reach 2% of the population is very successful. But for now, advertising is stuck in a rut, and it needs to change.

**Photographing People**
People are the most interesting subjects. A photo with someone in it is usually more interesting than a photo without. But people are also the hardest to take a good photo of. You need to think about their actions, gestures, and expressions. And sometimes the camera can make them feel uncomfortable.
**Taking Group Photos**
When taking a group photo, try not to have everyone stand in a straight line. Ask them to stand at different angles and distances. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so everyone's face is visible.
**Posing for Photos**
When someone is taking a photo of you, they might feel stiff and unnatural. Try to help them relax by suggesting a comfortable position. You can suggest they put their hands in their pockets or fold their arms.
**The Right Approach**
Don't pretend you're not taking a photo when you are. This can make people feel uncomfortable and even angry. Most people are happy to have their photo taken and are flattered by it. But they might feel self-conscious and need some direction.
**Eye Contact**
A photo is more interesting if the person in it is looking directly at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens, but not necessarily smile. This will give you a good photo.
**Candid Concentration**
An alternative to direct eye contact is to have the person concentrate on something in the photo. This can be easier for them and make the photo more interesting.
**Expressions and Gestures**
The expressions and gestures of the person in the photo can tell us more about them than anything else. Look for familiar expressions like smiling, laughing, or frowning.
**Situational Interest**
The background or environment of the photo can add interest and tell us more about the person. Try to exclude details that are not important to the person and make sure they are not overwhelmed by the background.
**Interaction**
Photos of people interacting with each other, like talking, arguing, or working together, can be very interesting. Look for eye contact or physical contact between the people in the photo.
**People and Places**
Photos of people in different places, like on holiday, can be interesting if taken well. Try to show the person against a relevant background and use a standard or wide-angle lens to get the whole scene in the frame.
**To Pose or Not to Pose?**
Decide why you want to take the photo. If you want a good clear photo, you might ask the person to pose. But if you want a more natural photo, you might prefer to take it on the spur of the moment.

Acupuncture is an old Chinese medicine that is over 2,000 years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which includes many different ways to stay healthy, such as taking herbs, getting massages, eating well, and exercising. Acupuncture is used to treat many different health problems, but doctors in the West are most interested in its use for pain relief.
Traditional Chinese medicine thinks that health is when the mind, body, and spirit are in balance. This balance is called Qi. Qi flows through the body along special paths called meridians. When the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, the body can become unwell. Acupuncturists try to find where the Qi is blocked and use special needles to help it flow again.
There are over 300 points on the body where the needles are placed. These points are related to the meridians and are not always near the area of pain. People often feel a gentle tingling sensation when the needle is inserted. This shows that the needle has reached the Qi.
Some doctors in the West have accepted that acupuncture can work for pain relief, even if they don't believe in the traditional Chinese theory. They think it might work because it can stimulate nerves and release natural pain-relieving substances.
Acupuncture can be used to treat many types of pain, including back pain, headaches, and arthritis. Some people use it as a last resort when other treatments haven't worked. Acupuncture is also used in some operations instead of anesthesia. This is a relatively new development, and it has helped convince some doctors that acupuncture is more than just a placebo.
It's hard to know how well acupuncture works because it's difficult to run clinical trials. However, most people who try acupuncture find it helpful for chronic pain. Acupuncturists usually need to see patients several times before they start to feel relief.
Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They try to find the underlying causes of the pain and take into account factors like the weather and the person's lifestyle. This is different from Western medicine, which often focuses on just the symptoms.
Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others don't believe in traditional Chinese theory. However, many traditional acupuncturists believe that this approach is the only way to bring about lasting changes. It's important to choose an acupuncturist carefully and to get a referral to a doctor if necessary.

Some people seem very confident, but most of them will tell you that it's a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asked five people how they did it.
A Jenny: I used to be very shy when I left school. But when I helped out at my daughter's school, I surprised myself by doing well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was nervous at first, but my confidence grew as I became more outgoing.
B Michaela: I had to take over my family business when my father got sick. I was scared and became a bit too bossy. But I learned that being confident means believing in yourself. When things get tough, I tell myself that I have nothing to lose. I also remind myself that fear makes us lack confidence.
C Lisa: People think I'm very confident, but actually, I'm often nervous. I've learned to look confident because it's important in my job. Interviewing people has shown me that we all get nervous in important situations. I feel calmer when I talk to someone friendly. My mother once told me, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone's too busy worrying about themselves.' I remember that and it helps me.
D Barbara: I've built my confidence over the years by enjoying my work and learning from my mistakes. If you just do your best and learn from your mistakes, you'll be more confident next time. I work hard and people like me, but I don't let it affect me. You have to like yourself for who you are, not try to be someone else.
